text: travelArticleText What do George Lucas, George Martin, and Shakespeare have in common? The fact that the places of Croatia were used as a setting for a play or as filming locations. As these stunning places attract not only writers and producers, we will share with you 3 most popular destinations for travelers. Dubrovnik Located about 50 km from Montenegro, Dubrovnik is the southernmost town in Croatia that was listed as UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979. The best time to visit Dubrovnik is from April to mid-June, and mid-September to mid-October. The most visited place in Dubrovnik is the old town, available only to pedestrians and surrounded by ancient walls. The old part of Dubrovnik is very well saved and filled with astonishing Renaissance, Gothic, and Baroque buildings, churches, and monasteries. After visiting the old town, explore Dubrovnik museums, among which Ethnographic museum Rupe, Dominican Monastery, tower Gornji Ugao, and Red History Museum. To grasp the whole beauty of the old town and enjoy it from the bird's view, you are welcomed to take a cable car ride, and it will take you from downtown about 800 meters up to the mount Srd. Besides the historical old town tour, you can enjoy taking the 'Game of Thrones' tour, where you will be guided through the filming locations of popular TV series. Zagreb The capital of Croatia, Zagreb, is also the largest city in the country. It originally existed as two different city centers: Kaptol, where mainly clerics resided, and Gradec, inhabited mainly by farmers and traders. In 1851, the Ban of Croatia (noble title) merged two cities in one under the name of Zagreb with the main city square named after Josip Jelačić. The best time to visit Zagreb is in spring and early summer. In early to mid-August, the temperature can be quite high and many locals take their holidays at this time, therefore you may find some of the local merchants’ shops and bars closed in this period. Spending your vacation in Zagreb, make sure to: Explore the Upper town - the oldest part of Zagreb that houses its top attractions: the Lotrscak tower, Stone gate, St. Marc Church, Stross promenade, the Mestrovic Atelier, and the Klovicevi Dvori gallery; Visit Downtown, filled with countless shops,  bars, and restaurants, located on Jelacic Square, Tkalciceva Street, Bogoviceva Street, and Cvjetni Trg (Flower’s Square); Attend museum of Broken relationships, where all featured items are relics of broken relationships; Come to the Technical Museum. Its main floor is dedicated to transport with a display of old cars, trains, planes, trams, as well as models of different ships and boats; Hike in Medvednica Mountain, located north of Zagreb. The most popular hike is up to the Puntijarka mountain house, located at the elevation of 957 m. Hvar Hvar is perhaps the most famous of all Croatian islands. It is located in central Dalmatia and between islands of Brac, Vis, Korcula, and Peljesac peninsula. The island is over 68 km long from northwest to southeast and is the longest Croatian island. The main tourist season starts in late June and lasts to early September, peaking at the end of July till the middle of August. On the island, plan an unhurried vacation to admire its beauty, visit the Stari Grad Hvar (the Old Town), and, of course, taste local wines. Stari Grad Hvar is the oldest settlement on the island. The old town consists of traditional stone buildings, stone-paved roads, and countless churches. One of the most fascinating places in town is Tvrdalj Castle, a palace from the 16th century. Plan a full-day wine tour while on the island of Hvar. Popular wine-producers are Zlatan Otok, Tomić Wines, PZ Svirce, Plancic Brothers, and others. Popular wine grape varieties include red plavac mali and white pošip.

travelArticleText.value:
What do George Lucas, George Martin, and Shakespeare have in common? The fact that the places of Croatia were used as a setting for a play or as filming locations. As these stunning places attract not only writers and producers, we will share with you 3 most popular destinations for travelers.

Dubrovnik

Located about 50 km from Montenegro, Dubrovnik is the southernmost town in Croatia that was listed as UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.

The best time to visit Dubrovnik is from April to mid-June, and mid-September to mid-October.

The most visited place in Dubrovnik is the old town, available only to pedestrians and surrounded by ancient walls. The old part of Dubrovnik is very well saved and filled with astonishing Renaissance, Gothic, and Baroque buildings, churches, and monasteries.

After visiting the old town, explore Dubrovnik museums, among which Ethnographic museum Rupe, Dominican Monastery, tower Gornji Ugao, and Red History Museum.

To grasp the whole beauty of the old town and enjoy it from the bird's view, you are welcomed to take a cable car ride, and it will take you from downtown about 800 meters up to the mount Srd.

Besides the historical old town tour, you can enjoy taking the 'Game of Thrones' tour, where you will be guided through the filming locations of popular TV series.

Zagreb

The capital of Croatia, Zagreb, is also the largest city in the country. It originally existed as two different city centers: Kaptol, where mainly clerics resided, and Gradec, inhabited mainly by farmers and traders.

In 1851, the Ban of Croatia (noble title) merged two cities in one under the name of Zagreb with the main city square named after Josip Jelačić.

The best time to visit Zagreb is in spring and early summer. In early to mid-August, the temperature can be quite high and many locals take their holidays at this time, therefore you may find some of the local merchants’ shops and bars closed in this period.

Spending your vacation in Zagreb, make sure to:

  • Explore the Upper town - the oldest part of Zagreb that houses its top attractions: the Lotrscak tower, Stone gate, St. Marc Church, Stross promenade, the Mestrovic Atelier, and the Klovicevi Dvori gallery;

  • Visit Downtown, filled with countless shops,  bars, and restaurants, located on Jelacic Square, Tkalciceva Street, Bogoviceva Street, and Cvjetni Trg (Flower’s Square);

  • Attend museum of Broken relationships, where all featured items are relics of broken relationships;

  • Come to the Technical Museum. Its main floor is dedicated to transport with a display of old cars, trains, planes, trams, as well as models of different ships and boats;

  • Hike in Medvednica Mountain, located north of Zagreb. The most popular hike is up to the Puntijarka mountain house, located at the elevation of 957 m.

Hvar

Hvar is perhaps the most famous of all Croatian islands. It is located in central Dalmatia and between islands of Brac, Vis, Korcula, and Peljesac peninsula.

The island is over 68 km long from northwest to southeast and is the longest Croatian island.

The main tourist season starts in late June and lasts to early September, peaking at the end of July till the middle of August.

On the island, plan an unhurried vacation to admire its beauty, visit the Stari Grad Hvar (the Old Town), and, of course, taste local wines.

Stari Grad Hvar is the oldest settlement on the island. The old town consists of traditional stone buildings, stone-paved roads, and countless churches. One of the most fascinating places in town is Tvrdalj Castle, a palace from the 16th century.

Plan a full-day wine tour while on the island of Hvar. Popular wine-producers are Zlatan Otok, Tomić Wines, PZ Svirce, Plancic Brothers, and others. Popular wine grape varieties include red plavac mali and white pošip.

text: travelArticleTitle The Hidden Three of Japan

travelArticleText Known mainly for Tokyo, with its futuristic neon skyscrapers, and Kyoto, filled with temples and gardens, Japan has a lot more to offer. It consists of over 6,800 islands, and each island is a stunning blend of wild nature and local culture. We picked 3 islands that are must-see on your next trip to Japan. Sado Location Sado Island is located near the coast of Niigata Prefecture and is one of the largest islands in Japan. Best time to visit Plan your visit to the island in August to attend the Earth Celebration. What to see Earth Celebration - Sado's biggest attraction, an annual music festival hosted by Sado's own, world-renowned Kodo taiko (Japanese drums) group. Sado Kinzan was the most profitable mine in the country, extracting about 400 kg of gold each year. Today the Sado Kinzan Gold Mine, with a museum inside, is open to the public. The Osado Skyline - a picturesque route in the Osado Mountains, going from the center of the island to the Sado Gold Mine, that offers scenic views of the island. Random Fact Due to its isolated and distant location, Sado served as a place for political exiles, like former Emperor Juntoku, the Buddhist monk Nichiren, and the founder of Noh theater, Zeami Motokiyo.   Iriomote Location Iriomote Island is one of the remote Yaeyama Islands in southwestern Japan. There are practically no buildings on the island, nearly 90% of Iriomote is covered by dense jungles and forests. Best time to visit Mid-June to mid-July in order to see Sagari-bana, one of the most beautiful Okinawan flowers. What to do Iriomote Island is best for exploring its land, hiking the trails to pristine waterfalls, kayaking through the forests, or navigating along one of the island's rivers that flows through the jungle. You can also visit tiny Yubu Island that is separated from the east coast of Iriomote Island by a shallow, sandy strait. You can ride across to the island in a cart pulled by a buffalo, while the driver plays the sanshin (an Okinawan stringed instrument) and entertains you with traditional songs. Random Fact Iriomote is the only habitat of the Iriomote cat, rare species of leopard that is critically endangered.   Ishikagi Location Ishigaki Island is the main island of the Yaeyama Islands and the region's transportation hub. The City of Ishigaki is the only downtown of the Yaeyama Islands with the region's main airport, harbor station, and a lot of authentic cafes, bars, and boutiques. Best time to visit From April till June: it is warm enough, and heavy rain season is not started. What to do Ishigaki Island has sandy beaches of incredible beauty that offer top-notch snorkeling and diving experience. Countless dive shops offer diving tours to coral reefs near the island. Ishigaki's rivers are perfect for kayaking, and various trails throughout the island's hilly terrain are good for hiking. Random Fact Ishigaki means “stone wall”. The island was named after the stone walls that were built along the streets of Ishigaki and still can be found in the city.

websiteTitle.value: Discover the world's best vacation destinations

missionStatementText.value:
At the Traveler, we believe in the uniting power of traveling. Experience gained from the journey unites people over the globe since even the most ordinary and short trip helps you to re-discover yourself, educating on different cultures, lifestyles, and other peoples' points of view.
The mission of the Traveler is to share this experience with everyone so that all of us could become a bit closer.

text: travelArticleText It would require a whole separate article just to list all of the architecture places one must see in Italy. And it would take months - if not years - to visit each of them. But do not despair, we list one significant architectural place in different cities in this article. These masterpieces are located not so far from the city centers, so you will not have a chance to miss them. Brunelleschi's Dome, Florence The dome at the top of the church of Santa Maria del Fiore (or simply Florence cathedral) is known as Filippo Brunelleschi’s dome. In 1418, the supervisor of the construction of Florence cathedral declared a contest for the construction of the dome with a reward of 200 gold florins for the winner. Following a number of debates, Filippo Brunelleschi was assigned as the head of the dome construction project. The construction of the Dome began on 7 August 1420 and was completed in 1436. At the time it was built, it was the largest dome in the world. Innovative construction for its time, this work is a masterpiece and witnesses the engineering genius of its creator. Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, Milan Located in the center of Milan, the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is the oldest Italian operating mall with the most luxurious stores in the city and is named after the first king of the Kingdom of Italy. The Galleria was designed by architect Giuseppe Mengoni in the Renaissance Revival style popular in those days. Constructed between 1865 and 1877, the building is formed by two arcades in the shape of Latin cross with the dome, made from iron and glass, at the top. After you walk around the Gallery and its boutiques, make sure to visit nearby sights: Duomo di Milano – the largest Gothic cathedral in the world that was built in the 14th century and took over 500 years to complete; La Scala – one of the most famous and beautiful opera houses in the world; Gallerie d’Italia – a famous art museum that exhibits contemporary Italian works from the 19th and 20th centuries. Basilica di San Marco, Venice St Mark's Basilica (officially named the Patriarchal Cathedral Basilica of Saint Mark) is the main cathedral church in Venice. The construction of the Basilica, initially planned as an extension of the Palazzo Ducale, started in 828 with the aim of storing Saint Mark’s relics that had been taken out of Alexandria. To access St Mark’s Basilica, you should wear clothes that cover your shoulders and are knee-length, otherwise, you might not be allowed in. Inside Basilica, visitors can also attend: The Museum and the Horses of St. Mark (Museo di San Marco), where you can observe the Basilica’s ceilings and mosaics closely and see the original sculptures of the Horses of St. Mark, the four gold-plated bronze horses brought from Constantinople. The Treasury, containing a collection of gold and silver items, that the Venetians brought after sacking Constantinople during the Fourth Crusade. The Pala d’Oro, a retable with gemstones created by medieval jewelers, located in the high altar of the Basilica.

Located in the center of Milan, the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is the oldest Italian operating mall with the most luxurious stores in the city and is named after the first king of the Kingdom of Italy.

The Galleria was designed by architect Giuseppe Mengoni in the Renaissance Revival style popular in those days. Constructed between 1865 and 1877, the building is formed by two arcades in the shape of Latin cross with the dome, made from iron and glass, at the top.

After you walk around the Gallery and its boutiques, make sure to visit nearby sights:

  • Duomo di Milano – the largest Gothic cathedral in the world that was built in the 14th century and took over 500 years to complete;
  • La Scala – one of the most famous and beautiful opera houses in the world;
  • Gallerie d’Italia – a famous art museum that exhibits contemporary Italian works from the 19th and 20th centuries.

Basilica di San Marco, Venice

St Mark's Basilica (officially named the Patriarchal Cathedral Basilica of Saint Mark) is the main cathedral church in Venice.

The construction of the Basilica, initially planned as an extension of the Palazzo Ducale, started in 828 with the aim of storing Saint Mark’s relics that had been taken out of Alexandria.

To access St Mark’s Basilica, you should wear clothes that cover your shoulders and are knee-length, otherwise, you might not be allowed in.

Inside Basilica, visitors can also attend:

  • The Museum and the Horses of St. Mark (Museo di San Marco), where you can observe the Basilica’s ceilings and mosaics closely and see the original sculptures of the Horses of St. Mark, the four gold-plated bronze horses brought from Constantinople.
  • The Treasury, containing a collection of gold and silver items, that the Venetians brought after sacking Constantinople during the Fourth Crusade.
  • The Pala d’Oro, a retable with gemstones created by medieval jewelers, located in the high altar of the Basilica.

text: travelArticleTitle A Quick Guide to Argentina

travelArticleText A place of tango origin, famous beef, and dozens of national parks, Argentina – once one of the wealthiest countries in the world – attracts millions of tourists each year, offering a wide range of social and cultural activities. Getting to Know Having the world’s eighth-largest country area and population of around 45 million, Argentina is one of the least densely populated countries on the planet. It is a multicultural country with significant European influences. Present Argentine culture was greatly influenced by Italian, Spanish, French and other European immigration. The country is divided into seven different regions with Buenos Aires, the capital of Argentina, in the Pampas region. Buenos Aires The population of Buenos Aires is around 2.8 million people. Throughout the years, many people have immigrated to Argentina's capital from different countries, creating a unique mix of their cultures with a notably strong European influence. Widely known as the cradle of tango, Buenos Aires is also home to first-class opera and theater, and to restaurants full of Mendoza wine and slices of beef right from the Pampas.         Patagonia For those who seek active adventures, Argentina offers Patagonia - a region with marvelous sceneries, famous for its hiking & trekking routes. The region is bordered in the north by the Cuyo and Pampas regions, by Chile's part of Patagonia in the west, by the Atlantic Ocean in the east, and by the archipelago of Tierra del Fuego on the south. The two most popular treks in the Argentinian part of Patagonia are Laguna de los Tres and Laguna Torre, which are of moderate difficulty. Expect seven to ten hours of hiking on a fairly light terrain. The best time for a trip to Patagonia is between the end of November and the beginning of March.   Famous Beaches of Argentina All of Argentina’s beaches are located on the Atlantic coast, a few hours’ ride from Buenos Aires. Hands down 3 most popular beaches that each traveler must visit: Mar del Plata – the number-one beach destination in Argentina. On summer vacations, it becomes a bit crowded, so for those seeking relaxation or alone time, it is better to look for other places (more distant from Buenos Aires, but still perfect sandy beaches). Pinamar – famous for its unique architecture, houses in blooming gardens, surrounding pinewoods, and a wide area of sand dunes known as “La Frontera”. Villa Gesell – a popular place for visitors in their 20s. It has a wood plank boardwalk along the beach and is known for its music stages and water sports in the summer.

asset.altText: Iguazu Falls in Argentina

imageDescription.value: Iguazu Falls are waterfalls of the Iguazu River, flowing along the border of the Argentine province of Misiones and the Brazilian state of Paraná. The waterfall system comprises 275 falls with the majority of the falls to be about 64 meteres in height. The most impressive one is the Devil’s Throat a U-shaped, 82 meters high, 150 meters wide and 700 meters long waterfall.

text: travelArticleTitle The Green City of Singapore

travelArticleText The city-state of Singapore is the greenest city in Asia, according to the Green City Index. Green buildings, developed to utilize resources in a more frugal way and be less harmful to the natural environment, have been acclaimed as a way to deal with climate change. The Building Construction Authority of Singapore aims for 80% of buildings to be certified as green ones under the national Green Mark certification by 2030. The most recent and - no doubts - most impressing green constructions of Singapore are Gardens by the Bay and Jewel of Changi Airport. Gardens by the Bay Gardens by the Bay is an urban outdoor recreation space and park that covers 101 hectares of land near the Marina Reservoir in the Central Region of Singapore. In 2018, Gardens had visitorship achieving a record high and exceeding 12 million. Since its inception, this national icon of Singapore has been visited over 56.2 million times (as of 31 March 2019). The park comprises three waterfront gardens: Bay South Garden, the largest of the three gardens, that was opened to the public on 29 June 2012, spans over 54 hectares and displays a big variety of tropical plants and garden artistry. Bay East Garden, spanning 32 hectares of land and designed as a group of tropical leaf-shaped gardens, offers a relaxing break from the busy city and amazing views of the city, parks, and gardens. Bay Central Garden is the garden that is currently under construction and will be a linkage between Bay South to Bay East with a waterfront boardwalk. Jewel of Changi Airport In April 2019, Changi Airport opened Jewel, a lifestyle place between the control tower and Terminal 1 of the airport. This ten-story construction comprises almost three hundred shops and restaurants. State-of-art dome of Jewel, made of glass and steel, required 4 years and US$1.25 billion to be built. The dome was designed by architect Moshe Safdie, whose previous works include one of the most famous hotels - Marina Bay Sands. Inside you can find an IMAX cinema, a full-sized supermarket, a hotel, and the Rain Vortex, the highest indoor waterfall in the world.

text: travelArticleText Kenya is a unique combination of the untouched culture of dozens of tribes, wildlife and the vibrant nightlife of cities. And if the nightlife is about the same in different cities across the globe, the nature of this country is what you have to come here for. Explore Kenya With a Remarkable Safari Kenya is considered the place where safari initially appeared. Vast magnificent national parks and conservancies are at your disposal to explore the wildlife of this country. It is one of the best places in Africa to see the "Big Five": lion, leopard, buffalo, elephant, and rhino. Perfect places for safari would be Masai Mara and Lake Nakuru. Other destinations, where you can see most of the "Big Five" include Tsavo East, Tsavo West, Amboseli, Laikipia Plateau, Samburu-Buffalo Springs-Shaba, Meru, and Shimba Hills.  See The Wilderness Beneath the Surface Another popular activity in Kenya is diving - an 'underwater safari' that provides a rare experience of exploring a large area of wild nature hidden beneath the surface of the Indian Ocean. Diving in Kenya is mostly fine throughout the year, although visibility decreases in July and August due to silting. The weather is almost always warm and sunny, with excellent water temperature, which creates ideal conditions for diving. Several first-class diving places that worth visiting include: Sites of the coast North of Mombasa, with the best ones in the Watamu Marine National Park; Dive site in the Canyon - a long sandy channel, bordered on each side by deep drop-offs; Sites at Mtwapa and Barracuda Reef, where you can see large shoals of angel and butterfly fish, and the world’s largest shark - the impressive Whale Shark.       Climb Africa’s Second-highest Mountain Mount Kenya is the highest mountain in Kenya (5,199 m) and second-highest in Africa, after Kilimanjaro (5,895 m). The main thing one has to remember about it is that the whole country of Kenya was named after this mountain. There are 12 slowly melting glaciers on the mountain and 4 secondary peaks that are at the head of the glacial valleys. With its glacier peaks and forested slopes, Mount Kenya is one of the most stunning sceneries in East Africa.

text: travelArticleTitle The Heritage and Nature of South Africa

travelArticleText Believed by some to be a cradle of humankind, South Africa houses a dozen historical places listed as World Heritage Sites by UNESCO. A wealth of sites, museums and galleries will be appreciated by a cultural traveler, but the country is also homeland to famous hiking routes in the mountains. Visit a World Heritage Site World Heritage Committee of UNESCO determined 10 heritage sites in South Africa, among which six are of cultural type, three are of natural type, and one is of a mixed (both cultural and natural) type. Be sure to visit the most important and famous places: The Fossil Hominid Sites, known as the Cradle of Humankind, is the place with the richest concentration of hominid fossils in the world, that shed light on the evolution of human over the past 3.5 million years. Robben Island is a symbol of democracy and victory over injustice, after Nelson Mandela, the first democratically elected president of South Africa, was kept in prison on the island for 18 years. Vredefort Dome is the area, where two billion years ago a meteorite ten kilometers in diameter hit the ground, creating a huge crater. Hike Amidst Stunning Scenery Blessed with a wide variety of natural environments, South Africa offers a jaw-dropping experience on any hiking trail you choose. There are many hiking routes to investigate, some of which take you along the picturesque shore, while others show you an amazing view of the country from the top of the mountains. Among the most famous routes are the Oystercatcher trail on the Garden Route coast, the Diamond Coast trail in Namaqualand, and the Num Num Trail in Mpumalanga.

text: travelArticleTitle The Overlooked Places of Peru

travelArticleText Known primarily for Machu Picchu, Peru has many more secret and unusual places that can amaze even an experienced traveler. These hidden gems have one undoubtful advantage over the well-known Machu Picchu – there are a lot fewer tourists. Visiting Peru, make sure that you dedicate some time to ancient Sacsayhuamán, Moray, and Ollantaytambo. Sacsayhuamán Thought to be constructed by Inca in the 13th century, Sacsayhuamán is an astonishing Inca fortress on the outskirts of Cusco, the historic capital of the Inca Empire. It is believed that more than twenty thousand men mined the stones from the quarries and carried them for 20 kilometers to the hill of Cusco. Only 40 percent of the Sacsayhuaman building's initial structure is retained. Even so, the fortress still has structures of more than 120 tons of weight and offers an amazing view of Cusco.   Moray Moray is the name of the Incan ruins near the Maras city, located 600 meters above the Sacred Valley of the Incas. These ruins are widely believed to be the crop laboratory of Inca that was likely used to cultivate resistant breeds of crops high in the Andes. Seeds cultivated at this laboratory were presumably sent throughout the Inca empire to increase crop yield in the tough conditions of the Andes. Today Moray is a series of circular agricultural terraces on plateaus 400 meters above the valley bottom. asset.altText: Penguins ashore in South Africa.

imageDescription.value:
Although it is commonly believed that penguins live only in distant and cold places as Antarctica, there are also penguins on the African continent.

The African penguin, also known as the Cape penguin, is a species that can be found on the south-western coast of Africa, with the first penguin colonies established near Cape Town, South Africa.

text: travelArticleTitle Top 3 Ski Resorts in the United States

travelArticleText The National Ski Areas Association, which maintains a list of ski resorts in the United States, counted 472 ski areas in 2019. Over 11 thousand kilometers of slopes are at your disposal for skiing in the United States. Although ski resorts can be found across the United States, most of the first-class areas are situated in the Western United States. In this article, we picked the top 3 destinations for skiing in a number-one state for this winter sport - Colorado. Jackson Hole About One of the most famous ski resorts in the United States, Jackson Hole is known for the best lift networks in the country and amazing terrain of incredible beauty. The mountain is covered with a lot of rocks and trees, thus half of it is considered to be mainly of expert skiing level, and about 40% and 10% of intermediate and beginner levels respectively. Getting there Jackson Hole is distant from major airports in Salt Lake City or Denver, but there is a regional airport that is served by 3 major airlines flying from many cities throughout the US.  Telluride About On average, the mountain has over 7.5 meters of snowfall annually and offers over 8 sq kilometers of skiing on 148 trails of varying difficulty: from kid-friendly beginner slopes to rugged off-piste trails. For beginners, Telluride offers the possibility to take a ride on an 8 km long green run starting from the top of Prospect Express at 3.6 km high. Intermediates can try slopes of Revelation Bowl sitting at 3.8 km, and experts can find the most challenging routes on Palmyra Peak at 4.1 km. Getting There Telluride is approximately 530 km from Denver. The nearest international airport to Telluride is Denver International Airport, but you can get closer to the resort via Telluride Regional Airport (10 km away) or via Montrose Regional Airport (105 km away). Vail About Vail is one of the most visited resorts in the country, because of the huge ski area (21.5 sq kilometers) and a remarkable village filled with countless hotels, bars, and restaurants. Thanks to the great variety of places in Vail village, this resort is perfect for everyone, even families with little kids and non-skiers. Getting There It is more convenient to get to Vail from the regional airport nearby, but you can also get from the Denver International Airport, although it takes more time to get to the resort. The Interstate 70 between Vail and Denver is shut down in heavy snowstorms, so travelers should take this fact into account during journey planning.

text: travelArticleTitle The 'Must Do' Guide for Canada

travelArticleText We hope you have enough time to spare. Because the most important thing to do in Canada is to see ALL of Canada. One of the largest countries in the world by the area that has 10% of the world's forest, the longest coastline, incredible mountains, and waterfalls - all this hints that in the first place you need to get acquainted with the nature of this beautiful country. Do canoeing One of the best ways to see Canada is by taking a trip on a canoe. There are hundreds of canoe routes across Canada, where you can enjoy seeing picturesque lakes, rivers, mountains, and wildlife, but make sure you add the following routes to your list: Johnstone Strait in British Columbia, where among typical Canadian wildlife (eagles, deer, otters, and seals) you can also see orca whales that feed on salmon from mid-summer to early autumn; Quetico Provincial Park in Ontario. The park area of 460 thousand hectares includes pine and spruce forests and more than 2,000 lakes. It operates from the mid-May to mid-October; Rideau Canal - a UNESCO World Heritage Site that connects the capital of Canada, Ottawa, with Kingston, Ontario.   Visit Niagara Falls Niagara Falls is one of the world’s most famous waterfalls and the most visited place in Canada. The Falls is not just one wide waterfall, but 3 connected waterfalls: American Falls - named so, since it flows mainly over the border of US; Bridal Veil Falls that resembles - surprise - a bridal veil; Horseshoe Falls, named because of its horseshoe shape, and it is also known as the Canadian Falls due to being mostly in Ontario.   Go skiing in Whistler Canadian ski resorts are located on both east and west coasts, but the west coast is a homeland to the most famous resorts like Banff, Lake Louise, and Whistler. Whistler is a 'flagship' resort in the country. It is conveniently located in the two-hour drive from Vancouver and has the biggest ski area in North America. The popularity of this place certainly has its drawbacks. In high season, it's getting too crowded, thus lift queues are not unusual, and too expensive, making you consider other resorts.

asset.altText: The building, where the parliament of Canada resides, with the national flag on the top.

imageDescription.value: Opened on June 6, 1866, Parliament Hill is the complex of 3 buildings in a Gothic Revival style with the Centre Block that houses the Canadian Parliament (the Senate and House of Commons) and connects it with the Library of Parliament and the Peace Tower, and the East and West blocks, which are administrative buildings.
